longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: An Ordinance to create new powers of investigation into organized crimes and certain other offences and into the proceeds of crime of certain offenders; provide for the confiscation of proceeds of crime; make provision in respect of the sentencing of certain offenders; create offences relating to the proceeds of crime or property representing the proceeds of crime; and for ancillary and connected matters.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Organized and Serious Crimes Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—

def.name: Absconded
def.leadIn: absconded (潛逃), in relation to a person, includes absconded for any reason whatsoever, and whether or not, before absconding, the person had been—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: taken into custody; or

paragraph.name: b
a
paragraph.content: any police officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any member of the Customs and Excise Service established by section 3 of the Customs and Excise Service Ordinance (Cap. 342); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other person authorized in writing by the Secretary for Justice for the purposes of this Ordinance; (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.def: confiscation order (沒收令) means an order made under section 8(7);

def.name: Dealing
def.leadIn: dealing (處理), in relation to property referred to in section 15(1) or 25, includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receiving or acquiring the property;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: disposing of or converting the property;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: bringing into or removing from Hong Kong the property;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: using the property to borrow money, or as security (whether by way of charge, mortgage or pledge or otherwise); (Added 90 of 1995 s. 2)

subsection.def: defendant (被告人) means a person against whom proceedings have been instituted for a specified offence (whether or not he has been convicted of that offence);

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Official Receiver; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any person acting as—

subparagraph.content: a trustee (including provisional trustee), interim trustee or special manager appointed under the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or (Amended 18 of 2005 s. 48)
a liquidator, provisional liquidator or special manager appointed under the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

def.name: ItemsSubjectToLegalPrivilege
def.leadIn: items subject to legal privilege (享有法律特權的品目) means—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: communications between a professional legal adviser and his client or any person representing his client or between such an adviser or his client or any such representative and any other person made in connection with or in contemplation of legal proceedings and for the purposes of such proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: items enclosed with or referred to in such communications and made—

subparagraph.content: in connection with the giving of legal advice; or
in connection with or in contemplation of legal proceedings and for the purposes of such proceedings,

paragraph.continued: when they are in the possession of a person who is entitled to possession of them,

def.continued: but excludes any such communications or items held with the intention of furthering a criminal purpose;

subsection.def: organized crime (有組織罪行) means a Schedule 1 offence that—(a)is connected with the activities of a particular triad society;(b)is related to the activities of 2 or more persons associated together solely or partly for the purpose of committing 2 or more acts, each of which is a Schedule 1 offence and involves substantial planning and organization; or(c)is committed by 2 or more persons, involves substantial planning and organization and involves—(i)loss of the life of any person, or a substantial risk of such a loss;(ii)serious bodily or psychological harm to any person, or a substantial risk of such harm; or(iii)serious loss of liberty of any person;

def.name: Premises
def.leadIn: premises (處所) includes any place and, in particular, includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any vehicle, vessel, aircraft, hovercraft or offshore structure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any tent or movable structure;

subsection.def: property (財產) includes both movable and immovable property within the meaning of section 3 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1);
Registrar (司法常務官) means the Registrar of the High Court; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
reward (酬賞) includes a pecuniary advantage;

def.name: Schedule1Offence
def.leadIn: Schedule 1 offence (附表1所列罪行) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any of the offences specified in Schedule 1;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: conspiracy to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inciting another to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: attempting to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of any of those offences;

subsection.def: society (社團) has the same meaning as in section 2(1) of the Societies Ordinance (Cap. 151);

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any of the offences specified in Schedule 1 or Schedule 2;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: conspiracy to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inciting another to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: attempting to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: e

def.name: TriadSociety
def.leadIn: triad society (三合會) includes any society which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: uses any ritual commonly used by triad societies, any ritual closely resembling any such ritual or any part of any such ritual; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: adopts or makes use of any triad title or nomenclature.

def.name: OrganizedCrime
def.leadIn: For the purpose of the definition of organized crime (有組織罪行) in subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a conspiracy to commit a Schedule 1 offence involves a matter referred to in paragraph (c)(i) to (iii) of that definition if the pursuit of the agreed course of conduct would at some stage involve that matter;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an attempt or incitement to commit a Schedule 1 offence involves a matter referred to in paragraph (c)(i) to (iii) of that definition if what the person attempting or inciting the commission had in view would involve that matter.

subsection.content:
The expressions listed in the left-hand column below are respectively defined or (as the case may be) fall to be construed in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance listed in the right-hand column in relation to those expressions.
Expression
Relevant provision
Charging order (押記令) Section 16(2)
Gift caught by this Ordinance (受本條例囿制的饋贈) ..................................
Section 12(9)
Making a gift (作出饋贈) Section 12(10)
Realisable property (可變現財產) Section 12(1)

This Ordinance applies to property whether it is situated in Hong Kong or elsewhere.

References in this Ordinance (except in sections 25 and 25A) to offences or organized crimes include a reference to offences or organized crimes committed before the commencement of this Ordinance; but nothing in this Ordinance imposes any duty or confers any power on any court in or in connection with proceedings against a person for an offence instituted before the commencement of this Ordinance. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a person’s proceeds of an offence are—

subparagraph.content: any property derived or realised, directly or indirectly, by him from any of the payments or other rewards; and
any pecuniary advantage obtained in connection with the commission of that offence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the value of the person’s proceeds of that offence is the aggregate of the values of—

subparagraph.content: the payments or other rewards;
that property; and
that pecuniary advantage. (Replaced 87 of 1997 s. 36)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a person’s proceeds of organized crime are—

subparagraph.content: any property derived or realised, directly or indirectly, by him from any of the payments or other rewards; and
any pecuniary advantage obtained in connection with the commission of one or more organized crimes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the value of the person’s proceeds of organized crime is the aggregate of the values of—

subparagraph.content: the payments or other rewards;
that property; and
that pecuniary advantage. (Replaced 87 of 1997 s. 36)

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Ordinance, a person who has at any time (whether before or after the commencement of this Ordinance) received any payment or other reward in connection with the commission of an offence or an organized crime has benefited from that offence or organized crime, as the case may be.

References in this Ordinance to property received in connection with the commission of an offence or organized crime include a reference to property received both in that connection and in some other connection.
Subsections (11) to (17) shall have effect for the interpretation of this Ordinance.
Property is held by any person if he holds any interest in it.
References to property held by a person include a reference to property vested in his trustee in bankruptcy or in a liquidator.

References to an interest held by a person beneficially in property include, where the property is vested in his trustee in bankruptcy or in a liquidator, a reference to an interest which would be held by him beneficially if the property were not so vested.
Property is transferred by one person to another if the first person transfers or grants to the other any interest in the property.

subsection.leadIn: Proceedings for an offence are instituted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when a magistrate issues a warrant or summons under section 72 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) in respect of the offence;

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: when a person has been arrested for the offence and released on bail or has refused bail; (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when a person is charged with the offence after being taken into custody without a warrant; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: when an indictment is preferred by the direction or with the consent of a judge under section 24A(1)(b) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221),

subsection.continued: and where the application of this subsection would result in there being more than one time for the institution of proceedings, they shall be taken to have been instituted at the earliest of those times.

subsection.leadIn: Proceedings for an offence are concluded on the occurrence of one of the following events—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the discontinuance of the proceedings whether by entry of a nolle prosequi or otherwise;

paragraph.name: b
c
d
paragraph.content: the grant of the Chief Executive’s pardon in respect of the conviction for the offence; (Amended 13 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the court or magistrate sentencing or otherwise dealing with him in respect of his conviction for the offence where the Secretary for Justice either does not apply for a confiscation order, or applies for a confiscation order and the order is not made; or (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the satisfaction of a confiscation order made in the proceedings (whether by payment of the amount due under the order or by the defendant serving imprisonment in default).

subsection.name: 16A
subsection.leadIn: An application for a confiscation order made in respect of a defendant where section 8(1)(a)(ii) or (7A) is applicable is concluded—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the Court of First Instance or the District Court decides not to make such an order, when it makes that decision; or (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if such an order is made as a result of that application, when the order is satisfied. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 2)

subsection.name: 16B
subsection.leadIn: An application under section 20(1A) in respect of a confiscation order made against a defendant is concluded—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the Court of First Instance decides not to vary that order, when it makes that decision; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Court of First Instance varies that order as a result of that application, when the order is satisfied. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: An order or verdict (including an order or verdict of acquittal) is subject to appeal or review so long as an appeal, further appeal or review is pending against the order or verdict; and for this purpose an appeal, further appeal or review shall be treated as pending (where one is competent but has not been instituted) until—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the expiration of the time prescribed for instituting the appeal, further appeal or review. (Amended 79 of 1995 s. 50)

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (19), nothing in this Ordinance shall require the disclosure of any items subject to legal privilege. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)
Subsection (18) shall not prejudice the operation of sections 3, 4 and 5. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

section.name: s3
section.heading: Requirement to furnish information or produce material

subsection.content: The Secretary for Justice may, for the purpose of an investigation into an organized crime, make an ex parte application to the Court of First Instance for an order under subsection (2) in relation to a particular person or to persons of a particular description. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

The Court of First Instance may, if on such an application it is satisfied that the conditions in subsection (4)(a), (b) and (d) or subsection (4)(a), (c) and (d) are fulfilled, make an order complying with subsection (3) in respect of the particular person, or persons of the particular description, to whom the application relates. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: An order under subsection (2) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give particulars of the organized crime under investigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identify the particular person, or state the particular description of persons, in respect of whom the order is made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: authorize the Secretary for Justice to require the person or persons in respect of whom the order is made—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to answer questions or otherwise furnish information with respect to any matter that reasonably appears to an authorized officer to be relevant to the investigation; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to produce any material that reasonably appears to the Secretary for Justice to relate to any matter relevant to the investigation, or any material of a class that reasonably appears to him so to relate,

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: contain such other terms (if any) as the Court of First Instance considers appropriate in the public interest, but nothing in this paragraph shall be construed as authorizing the court to order the detention of any person in custody without that person’s consent. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the organized crime under investigation has been committed;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: where the application relates to persons of a particular description, that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that some or all persons of that description have such information or are in possession of such material; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the organized crime could not effectively be investigated if the application was required to relate to a particular person, whether because of the urgency of the investigation, the need to keep the investigation confidential or the difficulty in identifying a particular person who has relevant information or material; (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 3)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: that there are reasonable grounds for believing that it is in the public interest, having regard—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to the seriousness of the organized crime under investigation;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to whether or not the organized crime could be effectively investigated if an order under subsection (2) is not made;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to the benefit likely to accrue to the investigation if the information is disclosed or the material obtained; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: to the circumstances under which the person or persons may have acquired, or may hold, the information or material (including any obligation of confidentiality in respect of the information or material and any family relationship with a person to whom the information or material relates),

paragraph.continued: that an order under subsection (2) should be made in respect of that person or those persons.

subsection.content: Where an order under subsection (2) authorizes the Secretary for Justice to require a person to answer questions or otherwise furnish information with respect to any matter that reasonably appears to an authorized officer to be relevant to an investigation, the Secretary for Justice may by one, or more than one, notice in writing served on that person require him to attend before an authorized officer at a specified time and place, or at specified times and places, and answer questions or otherwise furnish information with respect to any matter that reasonably appears to the authorized officer to be relevant to the investigation. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

Where an order under subsection (2) authorizes the Secretary for Justice to require a person to produce any material that reasonably appears to the Secretary for Justice to relate to any matter relevant to an investigation, or any material of a class that reasonably appears to him so to relate, the Secretary for Justice may by one, or more than one, notice in writing served on that person require him to produce at a specified time and place, or at specified times and places, any specified material that reasonably appears to him so to relate or any material of a specified class that reasonably appears to him so to relate. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: A notice in writing imposing a requirement on a person under subsection (5) or (6) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: state that a court order has been made under this section and include—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the date of the order;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the particulars of the organized crime under investigation;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: where the order is made in respect of that particular person, a statement to that effect;

subparagraph.name: iv
v
subparagraph.content: a statement of the authorization given to the Secretary for Justice by the order; and (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: a statement of any other terms of the order relevant to that person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: have annexed to it a copy of the order made under this section, but there may be excluded from such copy—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: any details in the order that relate only to such particular person or persons of a particular description; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be substantially in the form specified in Schedule 4 in relation to such notice and in addition shall set out or have annexed to it subsections (8) to (10) and section 7.

subsection.content: An authorized officer may photograph or make copies of any material produced in compliance with a requirement under this section.

A person shall not under this section be required to furnish any information or produce any material relating to items subject to legal privilege, except that a lawyer may be required to furnish the name and address of his client.

An order under subsection (2), and a notice in writing imposing a requirement under subsection (5) or (6), may be made in relation to information held by, and material in the possession of, a public body as defined in section 28.

subsection.leadIn: A person is not excused from furnishing information or producing any material required under this section on the ground that to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: might tend to incriminate him; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would breach an obligation as to secrecy or another restriction upon the disclosure of information or material imposed by statute or otherwise.

subsection.leadIn: A statement by a person in response to a requirement imposed by virtue of this section may not be used against him in criminal proceedings against him except as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in evidence in proceedings under subsection (14) or section 36 of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purpose of impeaching his credibility in proceedings in respect of any offence where in giving evidence he makes a statement inconsistent with it.

subsection.content: Any person who without reasonable excuse fails to comply with a requirement imposed on him under this section commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who, in purported compliance with a requirement under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes a statement that he knows to be false or misleading in a material particular; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recklessly makes a statement that is false or misleading in a material particular,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

subsection.content: Where an order under subsection (2) has been made the Secretary for Justice, or a person authorized in writing by the Secretary for Justice for the purpose of this subsection, may, after satisfying any conditions that may be prescribed by rules of court in this respect, obtain a copy of the order; but subject to the foregoing part of this subsection and to subsection (7)(b), no person is entitled to obtain a copy of the order or any part of the order. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: Where a requirement imposed on a person under this section relates to material which consists of information recorded otherwise than in legible form—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the requirement shall have effect as a requirement to produce the material in a form in which it can be taken away;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an authorized officer may by notice in writing served on the person require the person to produce at a specified time and place, or at specified times and places, the material in a form in which it is visible and legible and can be taken away, and may by like notice release the person from any obligation under the requirement to produce the material in the form in which it is recorded.

subsection.content: An application for the discharge or variation of an order made under this section may be made by any person on whom a requirement is imposed under the order.

subsection.leadIn: Rules of court—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: may provide for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: proceedings relating to orders under this section;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: conditions that must be satisfied before a person (including the Secretary for Justice) referred to in subsection (15) may obtain a copy of such order. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 3; L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Security shall prepare a code of practice in connection with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the exercise of any of the powers conferred; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the discharge of any of the duties imposed,

subsection.continued: by this section, and any such code shall be laid before the Legislative Council and shall not be promulgated until the code has been approved by the Legislative Council.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Order to make material available

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Justice or an authorized officer may, for the purpose of an investigation into—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an organized crime; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proceeds of organized crime of any person who has committed or is suspected of having committed an organized crime; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the proceeds of a specified offence of any person who has committed, or is suspected of having committed, that specified offence,

subsection.continued: make an ex parte application to the Court of First Instance for an order under subsection (2) in relation to particular material or material of a particular description, whether in Hong Kong or, in the case of an application by the Secretary for Justice, elsewhere. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5) and section 28(10), the court may, if on such an application it is satisfied that the conditions in subsection (4)(a), (c) and (d) or subsection (4)(b), (c) and (d) are fulfilled, make an order that the person who appears to the court to be in possession or control of the material to which the application relates shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: produce the material to an authorized officer for him to take away; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give an authorized officer access to it,

subsection.continued: within such period as the order may specify.

subsection.content: The period to be specified in an order under subsection (2) shall be 7 days unless it appears to the court that a longer or shorter period would be appropriate in the particular circumstances of the application.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: where the investigation is into the proceeds of organized crime or a specified offence of a person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the person has committed an organized crime or that specified offence, or that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that he has committed an organized crime or that specified offence; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the person has benefited from organized crime or that specified offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the material to which the application relates—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is likely to be relevant to the investigation for the purpose of which the application is made; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: does not consist of or include items subject to legal privilege;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: that there are reasonable grounds for believing that it is in the public interest, having regard—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to the benefit likely to accrue to the investigation if the material is obtained; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to the circumstances under which the person in possession or control of the material holds or controls it, as the case may be, (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 4)

paragraph.continued: that the material should be produced or that access to it should be given.

subsection.content: Where an application under subsection (1) relates to material of a particular description, an order under subsection (2) shall only be made where an application in relation to particular material is not reasonably practicable.

Where a court makes an order under subsection (2)(b) in relation to material on any premises it may, on the same or a subsequent application of an authorized officer, order any person who appears to it to be entitled to grant entry to the premises to allow an authorized officer to enter the premises to obtain access to the material.
An application for the discharge or variation of an order made under subsection (2) or (6) may be made by any person who is subject to the order.

subsection.leadIn: Rules of court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall provide for applications by any person who is subject to an order made under this section for the discharge or variation of such order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may provide for proceedings relating to orders under this section.

subsection.leadIn: Where material to which an application under this section relates consists of information recorded otherwise than in legible form—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under subsection (2)(a) shall have effect as an order to produce the material in a form in which it can be taken away; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order under subsection (2)(b) shall have effect as an order to give access to the material in a form in which it is visible and legible.

subsection.content: Where an order made under subsection (2)(a) relates to information recorded otherwise than in legible form, an authorized officer may by notice in writing require the person to produce the material in a form in which it is visible and legible and can be taken away, and may by like notice release the person from any obligation under the order to produce the material in the form in which it was recorded.

subsection.leadIn: An order under subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not confer any right to production of, or access to, items subject to legal privilege; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be made in relation to material in the possession or control of a public body as defined in section 28. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: A person is not excused from producing any material in relation to which an order under subsection (2) is made on the ground that to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: might tend to incriminate him; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would breach an obligation as to secrecy or another restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by statute or otherwise.

subsection.content: Any person who without reasonable excuse fails to comply with an order made under subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year.
An authorized officer may photograph or make copies of any material produced under this section.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Authority for search

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may, for the purpose of an investigation into—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an organized crime;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proceeds of organized crime of any person who has committed or is suspected of having committed an organized crime;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the proceeds of a specified offence of any person who has committed, or is suspected of having committed, that specified offence,

subsection.continued: apply to the Court of First Instance or the District Court for a warrant under this section in relation to specified premises. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: On such application the court may issue a warrant authorizing an authorized officer to enter and search the premises if it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a requirement imposed under section 3(6) in relation to material on the premises has not been complied with; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that an order made under section 4 in relation to material on the premises has not been complied with; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the conditions in subsection (3)(a), (c) and (d) or subsection (3)(b), (c) and (d) are fulfilled; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that the conditions in subsection (4)(a), (c) and (d) or subsection (4)(b), (c) and (d) are fulfilled.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (2)(c) are—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: where the investigation is into the proceeds of organized crime or a specified offence of a person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the person has committed an organized crime or that specified offence, or that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that he has committed an organized crime or that specified offence; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the person has benefited from organized crime or that specified offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the conditions in section 4(4)(c) and (d) are fulfilled in relation to any material on the premises;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: that it would not be appropriate to make an order under that section in relation to the material because—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to communicate with any person entitled to produce the material; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to communicate with any person entitled to grant access to the material or entitled to grant entry to the premises on which the material is situated; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the investigation for the purposes of which the application is made might be seriously prejudiced unless an authorized officer could secure immediate access to the material.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (2)(d) are—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: where the investigation is into the proceeds of organized crime or a specified offence of a person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the person has committed an organized crime or that specified offence, or that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that he has committed an organized crime or that specified offence; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the person has benefited from organized crime or that specified offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that there is on the premises material which is likely to be relevant to the investigation for the purpose of which the application is made, but that the material cannot at the time of the application be particularized;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to communicate with any person entitled to grant entry to the premises; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: entry to the premises will not be granted unless a warrant is produced; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the investigation for the purposes of which the application is made might be seriously prejudiced unless an authorized officer arriving at the premises could secure immediate entry to them.

subsection.content: Where an authorized officer has entered premises in the execution of a warrant issued under this section, he may seize and retain any material, other than items subject to legal privilege, which is likely to be relevant to the investigation for the purpose of which the warrant was issued.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who hinders or obstructs an authorized officer in the execution of a warrant issued under this section commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: An authorized officer may photograph or make copies of any material seized under this section.

Notwithstanding section 83 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1), but subject to this section, a warrant may be issued under this section authorizing entry to premises for the purpose of searching for or seizing material which is known or suspected to be journalistic material. (Added 88 of 1995 s. 6)

section.name: s6
section.heading: Disclosure of information obtained under section 3, 4 or 5

subsection.leadIn: Where any information subject to an obligation of secrecy under the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112) has been obtained from the Commissioner of Inland Revenue or any officer of the Inland Revenue Department under or by virtue of section 3, 4 or 5, that information may be disclosed by any authorized officer to the Secretary for Justice for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any prosecution of a specified offence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any application for a confiscation order; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any application for an order under section 15(1) or 16(1),

subsection.continued: but may not otherwise be disclosed.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (1), information obtained by any person under or by virtue of section 3, 4 or 5 may be disclosed by any authorized officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the Department of Justice, the Hong Kong Police Force, the Customs and Excise Department, the Immigration Department, and the Independent Commission Against Corruption; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the information appears to the Secretary for Justice to be likely to assist any corresponding person or body to discharge its functions, to that person or body.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) is without prejudice to any other right to disclose information obtained under or by virtue of section 3, 4 or 5 that may exist apart from subsection (2).

subsection.def: In this section, corresponding person or body (相應的人員或機構) means any person who or body which, in the opinion of the Secretary for Justice, has under the law of a place outside Hong Kong, functions corresponding to any of the functions of any body mentioned in subsection (2)(a).

section.name: s7
section.heading: Offence of prejudicing investigation

subsection.leadIn: Where an order under section 3 or 4 has been made or has been applied for and has not been refused or a warrant under section 5 has been issued, a person who, knowing or suspecting that the investigation in relation to which the order has been made or applied for or the warrant has been issued is taking place—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without lawful authority or reasonable excuse makes any disclosure intending to prejudice the investigation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: falsifies, conceals, destroys or otherwise disposes of, or causes or permits the falsification, concealment, destruction or disposal of any material—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: knowing or suspecting that the material is likely to be relevant to the investigation; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: intending to conceal the facts disclosed by the material from persons carrying out the investigation,

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.content: Where a person has been arrested in connection with an investigation specified in subsection (1), that subsection shall not apply as regards any disclosure in respect of the investigation made after such arrest.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine and to imprisonment for 7 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Confiscation orders

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in proceedings before the Court of First Instance or the District Court a person is to be sentenced in respect of one or more specified offences and has not previously been sentenced in respect of his conviction for the offence or, as the case may be, any of the offences concerned; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: proceedings for one or more specified offences have been instituted against a person but have not been concluded because the person—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: has died; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: has absconded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application is made by or on behalf of the Secretary for Justice for a confiscation order, (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, shall act as follows. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 6. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: The court shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where subsection (1)(a)(i) is applicable—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.leadIn: then, or where no request has been made under subparagraph (i), first—

subparagraph.name: A
B
subparagraph.leadIn: make such order or orders (other than a confiscation order) in relation to sentence as is appropriate in respect of the offence or, as the case may be, the offences concerned, and such order or orders may be or include any order—

subparagraph.name: I
subparagraph.content: imposing any fine on the person;

subparagraph.name: II
subparagraph.content: involving any payment by the person; or

subparagraph.name: III
subparagraph.content: under section 38F or 56 of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134), or under section 72, 84A, 102 or 103 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where subsection (1)(a)(ii)(A) is applicable—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the person has died; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: having regard to all relevant matters before it, the person could have been convicted in respect of the offence or, as the case may be, the offences concerned;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: then, where the court is satisfied under subparagraph (i), determine, if the prosecution so requests, whether the offence or any of the offences concerned could have been an organized crime;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: where subsection (1)(a)(ii)(B) is applicable—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the person has absconded and that not less than 6 months have elapsed beginning with the date which is, in the opinion of the court, the date on which the person absconded;

subparagraph.name: I
subparagraph.leadIn: a person who is known to be outside Hong Kong and whose exact whereabouts are known—

subparagraph.name: aa
subparagraph.content: reasonable steps have been taken, but have been unsuccessful, to obtain the return of that person to Hong Kong for the purposes of the proceedings concerned;

subparagraph.name: bb
subparagraph.content: if that person is in custody outside Hong Kong for purposes other than the purposes referred to in sub-sub-sub-subparagraph (aa), he is in such custody by virtue of conduct which would constitute an indictable offence if it had occurred in Hong Kong; and

subparagraph.name: cc
II
subparagraph.content: subject to subsection (3A), a person whose exact whereabouts are not known, reasonable steps have been taken to ascertain the person’s whereabouts (including, if appropriate, a step mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) or rule 5(1) of Order 65 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A)) and notice of those proceedings, addressed to that person, has been published in a Chinese language newspaper, and an English language newspaper, circulating generally in Hong Kong; and (Replaced 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: having regard to all relevant matters before it, the person could have been convicted in respect of the offence or, as the case may be, the offences concerned;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: then, where the court is satisfied under subparagraph (i), determine, if the prosecution so requests, whether the offence or any of the offences concerned could have been an organized crime. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Where subsection (3)(c)(i)(B)(II) is applicable, and notwithstanding that the court is satisfied as mentioned in that subsection that actions have been taken, the court may, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so, require that notice of the proceedings mentioned in that subsection be given to the person mentioned in that subsection in such additional manner as the court may direct. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: The court shall then determine—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where subsection (1)(a)(i) is applicable, whether the person has benefited from the specified offence or from that offence taken together with any specified offence of which he is convicted in the same proceedings, or which the court proposes to take or has taken into consideration in determining his sentence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where subsection (1)(a)(ii) is applicable, whether the person has benefited from the specified offence of which the court is satisfied that he could have been convicted or from that offence taken together with any specified offence of which the court is satisfied that he could have been convicted in the same proceedings or which the court could have taken into consideration in determining his sentence if he had not died or absconded, as the case may be,

subsection.continued: and, if he has, whether his proceeds of that specified offence or offences are in total at least $100,000. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: If the court has determined—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where subsection (1)(a)(i) is applicable—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: under subsection (3)(a)(i), that the specified offence or any of the specified offences of which the person stands convicted is an organized crime; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under subsection (4), that his proceeds of the specified offence or offences referred to in that subsection are in total at least the amount specified in that subsection;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where subsection (1)(a)(ii) is applicable—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: under subsection (3)(b)(ii) or (c)(ii), as the case may be, that the specified offence or any of the specified offences concerned could have been an organized crime; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under subsection (4), that his proceeds of the specified offence or offences referred to in that subsection are in total at least the amount specified in that subsection,

subsection.continued: the court shall then determine whether the person has benefited from organized crime. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.content: If the court determines that his proceeds of the specified offence or offences are in total at least the amount specified in subsection (4), the court shall determine in accordance with section 11 the amount to be recovered in his case by virtue of this section.

subsection.leadIn: The court shall then, in respect of the offence or offences concerned, order the person to pay—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that amount; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (a), such proportion of that amount as it thinks fits after taking into account any order or orders provided for or referred to in subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I), (II) or (III) which has or have been made in respect of the person. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 7A
subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person has been convicted of one or more specified offences;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the person has died or absconded before that application has been concluded,

subsection.continued: then that application may still be concluded notwithstanding that death or abscondment, as the case may be. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 7B
subsection.leadIn: Where subsection (7A) is applicable in relation to a person who has died—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subsection (3)(a)(ii)(A) shall not apply in relation to the person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the court shall not make a confiscation order against the person unless it is satisfied that the person has died. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 7C
subsection.leadIn: Where subsection (7A) is applicable in relation to a person who has absconded, the court shall not make a confiscation order against the person unless it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person has absconded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: a person who is known to be outside Hong Kong and whose exact whereabouts are known—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: reasonable steps have been taken, but have been unsuccessful, to obtain the return of that person to Hong Kong for the purposes of the proceedings concerned; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: notice of those proceedings was given to that person in sufficient time to enable him to defend them;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (7D), a person whose exact whereabouts are not known—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: reasonable steps have been taken to ascertain the person’s whereabouts (including, if appropriate, a step mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of rule 5(1) of Order 65 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A)); and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: notice of those proceedings, addressed to that person, has been published in a Chinese language newspaper, and an English language newspaper, circulating generally in Hong Kong. (Replaced 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.name: 7D
subsection.content: Where subsection (7C)(b)(ii) is applicable, and notwithstanding that the court is satisfied as mentioned in that subsection that actions have been taken, the court may, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so, require that notice of the proceedings mentioned in that subsection be given to the person mentioned in that subsection in such additional manner as the court may direct. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

For the purposes of subsection (3)(b)(i)(B) or (ii) or (c)(i)(C) or (ii), information may be furnished to the court after the person has died or absconded, as the case may be. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 8A
subsection.content: For the purposes of any Ordinance conferring rights of appeal in criminal cases, a confiscation order made against a person shall be deemed to be a sentence passed on that person in respect of the offence or offences concerned and, in the case of any such person who has died (whether before or after the making of such order), his personal representative may act on his behalf for those purposes. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 8B
subsection.leadIn: It is hereby declared that the standard of proof required to determine any question arising under this Ordinance as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether a person has benefited from a specified offence or offences;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether a person has benefited from organized crime; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the amount to be recovered in his case in pursuance of a confiscation order,

subsection.continued: shall be on the balance of probabilities. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 8C
subsection.leadIn: The fact that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: under subsection (3)(b)(i)(B) or (c)(i)(C) the court is satisfied that a person could have been convicted in respect of the offence or, as the case may be, the offences concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: under subsection (3)(b)(ii) or (c)(ii) the court determines that the offence or any of the offences referred to in subsection (3)(b)(i)(B) or (c)(i)(C) could have been an organized crime,

subsection.continued: shall not be admissible in evidence in any proceedings for an offence. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 8D
subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that where an application is made for a confiscation order in any case where subsection (1)(a)(ii)(A) is applicable, the personal representatives of the deceased person concerned shall, for the purposes of opposing the application, be entitled to be heard on the application and to call, examine and cross-examine any witness. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 8E
subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before the commencement of the Organized and Serious Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 1995 (90 of 1995), proceedings for one or more specified offences have been instituted against a person but have not been concluded because that person has absconded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: immediately before that commencement, any realisable property of that person is the subject of a charging order or restraint order,

subsection.continued: then the provisions of this Ordinance as amended by that Ordinance shall apply in relation to that person as they would apply in relation to a person against whom, on or after that commencement, proceedings for one or more specified offences have been instituted but have not been concluded because that last-mentioned person has absconded. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.name: 8F
subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: before the commencement of the Organized and Serious Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 1995 (90 of 1995)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a person has been convicted of one or more specified offences;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an application for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the person; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the person has absconded before that application has been concluded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: immediately before that commencement, any realisable property of that person is the subject of a charging order or restraint order,

subsection.continued: then the provisions of this Ordinance as amended by that Ordinance shall apply in relation to that person as they would apply in relation to a person to whom subsection (7A) is applicable because he has absconded. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subsection (3)(a)(i), (b)(ii) or (c)(ii), the court shall only have regard to evidence such as would be admissible in criminal proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subsection (3)(a)(i), the court shall only make a determination that a specified offence is an organized crime if it is so satisfied beyond reasonable doubt. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.content: Where subsection (1)(a)(ii)(A) or (B) is applicable, the reference in that subsection to one or more specified offences includes any offence previously specified in Schedule 1 or 2, and the other provisions of this section and this Ordinance (including paragraphs (b) to (e) of the definition of specified offence in section 2(1) and any subsidiary legislation) shall be construed accordingly. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

section.name: s9
section.heading: Assessing the proceeds of crime

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, may, for the purpose of determining whether— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where section 8(1)(a)(i) is applicable, a person convicted of a specified offence and found to have committed an organized crime;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where section 8(1)(a)(ii)(A) or (B) is applicable, a person whom the court is satisfied that he could have been convicted of a specified offence being an offence which the court determines that it could have been an organized crime,

subsection.continued: has benefited from organized crime, and if he has, of assessing the value of his proceeds of organized crime, make the following assumptions, except to the extent that the defendant (or, in the case of a defendant who has died, his personal representative on his behalf) shows that any of the assumptions are incorrect in his case. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 7)

subsection.leadIn: Those assumptions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that any property appearing to the court—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: to have been held by him at any time—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: since his conviction; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: where section 8(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, since the application was made for a confiscation order in his case,

subparagraph.continued: as the case may be; or (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 7)

subparagraph.content: to have been transferred to him at any time since the beginning of the period of 6 years ending when the proceedings were instituted against him,

paragraph.continued: was received by him, at the earliest time at which he appears to the court to have held it, as his proceeds of organized crime; (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 7)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that any expenditure of his since the beginning of that period was met out of his proceeds of organized crime; and (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 7)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that, for the purpose of valuing any property received or assumed to have been received by him at any time as his proceeds of organized crime, he received the property free of any other interests in it. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 7)

subsection.content: For the purpose of assessing the value of the defendant’s proceeds of organized crime in a case where a confiscation order, or an order under section 3(6) of the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance (Cap. 405), has previously been made against him, the court shall leave out of account any proceeds of organized crime that are shown to the court to have been taken into account in determining the amount to be recovered under that order.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Statements, etc. relevant to making confiscation order

subsection.leadIn: Where an application is made for a confiscation order, the prosecutor may tender to the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, a statement of matters relevant to any of the following— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where section 8(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, determining—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether the defendant could have been convicted in respect of the offence or, as the case may be, the offences concerned;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether the offence or any of the offences concerned could have been an organized crime;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determining whether the defendant has benefited from a specified offence or an organized crime;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: assessing the value of the defendant’s proceeds of a specified offence or an organized crime. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Where any statement has been tendered under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the prosecutor may at any time tender to the court a further such statement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the court may at any time require the prosecutor to tender to it a further such statement within such period as it may direct. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: Where any statement has been tendered under subsection (1) and the court is satisfied that a copy of the statement has been served on the defendant, it may require the defendant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to indicate to it, within such period as it may direct, the extent to which he accepts each allegation in the statement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so far as he does not accept any such allegation, to give particulars of any matters on which he proposes to rely. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.content: Where the court has given a direction under this section, it may at any time vary it by giving a further direction. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: Where the defendant accepts to any extent any allegation in any statement tendered under subsection (1), the court may, for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where section 8(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, determining—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether the defendant could have been convicted in respect of the offence or, as the case may be, the offences concerned;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether the offence or any of the offences concerned could have been an organized crime;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determining whether the defendant has benefited from a specified offence or an organized crime; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: assessing the value of his proceeds of a specified offence or an organized crime,

subsection.continued: treat his acceptance as conclusive of the matters to which the allegation relates. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: If the defendant fails in any respect to comply with a requirement under subsection (1B), he may be treated for the purposes of this section as accepting every allegation in the statement apart from— (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any allegation in respect of which he has complied with the requirement; (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 8)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where section 8(1)(a)(ii) is applicable—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any allegation that he could have been convicted in respect of the offence or, as the case may be, the offences concerned;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any allegation that the offence or any of the offences concerned could have been an organized crime; (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 8)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any allegation that he has benefited from a specified offence or organized crime; and (Added 90 of 1995 s. 8)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any allegation that any payment or other reward was received by him in connection with the commission of a specified offence or an organized crime. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the defendant tenders to the court a statement as to any matters relevant to determining the amount that might be realised at the time the confiscation order is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the prosecutor accepts to any extent any allegation in the statement,

subsection.continued: the court may, for the purposes of that determination, treat the acceptance by the prosecutor as conclusive of the matters to which it relates.

subsection.content: An allegation may be accepted, or particulars of any matter may be given, for the purposes of this section in writing in a form acceptable to the court. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: No acceptance by the defendant under this section that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where section 8(1)(a)(ii) is applicable—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: he could have been convicted in respect of the offence or, as the case may be, the offences concerned;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the offence or any of the offences concerned could have been an organized crime; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any payment or other reward was received by him in connection with the commission of a specified offence or an organized crime,

subsection.continued: shall be admissible in evidence in any proceedings for an offence. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings on an application made for a confiscation order where section 8(1)(a)(ii) or (7A) is applicable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the defendant has died, subsection (1B) shall have effect as if it required a copy of the statement tendered under subsection (1) to be served on the defendant’s personal representative;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the defendant has absconded and section 8(3)(c)(i)(B)(I) or (7C)(b)(i) is not applicable to him, this section shall have effect as if a copy of the statement tendered under subsection (1) had been served on the defendant. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that, where section 8(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, this section shall not prejudice the generality of section 8(8). (Added 90 of 1995 s. 8)

For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that an allegation may be accepted under this section, and may always have been so accepted, whether or not subsection (7)(a) or (b) is applicable to the defendant, and subsection (3) shall be construed accordingly. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

section.name: s11
section.heading: Amount to be recovered under confiscation order

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), the amount to be recovered in the defendant’s case under the confiscation order shall be the amount the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, assesses to be the value of the defendant’s proceeds of any specified offence to which section 8(4) applies or, where the court has determined under section 8(3)(a)(i) that a specified offence is an organized crime or under section 8(3)(b)(ii) or (c)(ii) that a specified offence could have been an organized crime, all organized crime which he has committed. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 9; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

If the court is satisfied as to any matter relevant for determining the amount that might be realised at the time the confiscation order is made (whether by an acceptance under section 10 or otherwise), the court may issue a certificate giving the court’s opinion as to the matters concerned and shall do so if satisfied as mentioned in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: If the court is satisfied that the amount that might be realised at the time the confiscation order is made is less than the amount the court assesses to be the value of the defendant’s proceeds for the purpose of subsection (1), the amount to be recovered in the defendant’s case under the confiscation order shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the amount appearing to the court to be so realised; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a nominal amount, where it appears to the court (on the information available to it at the time) that the amount that might be so realised is nil. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 9)

section.name: s11A
section.heading: Interest on amounts to be recovered under confiscation orders

subsection.leadIn: The amount to be recovered under a confiscation order shall be treated as a judgment debt for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: where the order was made by the District Court, section 50 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336),

subsection.continued: and, for those purposes, the date of the confiscation order shall be treated as the date of the judgment debt.

subsection.content: Where by virtue of subsection (1) any interest accrues on the amount to be recovered under a confiscation order, the defendant shall be liable to pay that interest and the amount of the interest shall for the purposes of enforcement be treated as part of the amount to be recovered from him under the confiscation order.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Definition of principal terms used

def.name: RealisableProperty
def.leadIn: In this Ordinance, realisable property (可變現財產) means, subject to subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any property held by a person to whom the defendant has directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance; and (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 11)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any property that is subject to the effective control of the defendant. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 11)

subsection.leadIn: Property is not realisable property if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 102 or 103 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order under section 38F or 56 of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an order under section 12AA(1) of the Prevention of Bribery Ordinance (Cap. 201),

subsection.continued: is in force in respect of the property.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance the amount that might be realised at the time a confiscation order is made against the defendant is— (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 11)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the total of the values at that time of all the realisable property held by the defendant, less

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where there are obligations having priority at that time, the total amounts payable in pursuance of such obligations,

subsection.continued: together with the total of the values at that time of all gifts caught by this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (5) to (10), for the purposes of this Ordinance the value of property (other than cash) in relation to any person holding the property—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where any other person holds an interest in the property, is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the market value of the first-mentioned person’s beneficial interest in the property, less

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the amount required to discharge any incumbrance (other than a charging order) on that interest; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, is its market value.

def.name: TheMaterialTime
def.leadIn: Subject to subsection (10), references in this Ordinance to the value at any time (referred to in subsection (6) as the material time (關鍵時間)) of a gift caught by this Ordinance or of any payment or reward are references to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the value of the gift, payment or reward to the recipient when he received it adjusted to take account of subsequent changes in the value of money; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where subsection (6) applies, the value there mentioned,

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (10), if at the material time the recipient holds—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the property which he received (not being cash); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: property which, in whole or in part, directly or indirectly represents in his hands the property which he received,

subsection.continued: the value referred to in subsection (5)(b) is the value to him at the material time of the property mentioned in paragraph (a) or, as the case may be, of the property mentioned in paragraph (b), so far as it so represents the property which he received, but disregarding in either case any charging order.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (3), an obligation has priority at any time if it is an obligation of the defendant to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: pay an amount due in respect of a fine, or other order of a court, imposed or made on conviction of an offence, where the fine was imposed or order made before the confiscation order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: pay any sum which, if the defendant had been adjudged bankrupt or was being wound up, would be among the preferential debts.

def.name: ThePreferentialDebts
def.leadIn: In subsection (7)(b), the preferential debts (優先債項)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to bankruptcy, means the debts to be paid in priority under section 38 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) (assuming the date of the confiscation order to be the date of filing of the petition and of the bankruptcy order made under that Ordinance); and (Amended 37 of 1998 s. 11)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to winding up, means the debts to be paid under section 265 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) (assuming the date of the confiscation order to be the date of commencement of the winding up and the relevant date for the purpose of that section). (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.leadIn: A gift (including a gift made before the commencement of this Ordinance) is caught by this Ordinance if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it was made by the defendant at any time since the beginning of the period of 6 years ending when the proceedings were instituted against him; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it was made by the defendant at any time and was a gift of property received by the defendant in connection with a specified offence or an organized crime committed by him or another; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it was made by the defendant at any time and was a gift of property which in whole or in part directly or indirectly represented in the defendant’s hands property received by him in that connection.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which the defendant is to be treated as making a gift include those where he transfers property to another person directly or indirectly for a consideration the value of which is significantly less than the value of the consideration provided by the defendant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in those circumstances, the preceding provisions of this section shall apply as if the defendant had made a gift of such share in the property as bears to the whole property the same proportion as the difference between the values referred to in paragraph (a) bears to the value of the consideration provided by the defendant.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: property, or an interest in property, may be subject to the effective control of the defendant whether or not the defendant has—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a legal or equitable estate or interest in the property; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a right, power or privilege in connection with the property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: without limiting the generality of any other provision of this Ordinance, in determining—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether or not property, or an interest in property, is subject to the effective control of the defendant; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether or not there are reasonable grounds to believe that property, or an interest in property, is subject to the effective control of the defendant,

paragraph.leadIn: regard may be had to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: shareholdings in, debentures over or directorships of a company that has an interest (whether direct or indirect) in the property;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: a trust that has a relationship to the property; and

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: family, domestic and business relationships between persons having an interest in the property, or in companies of the kind referred to in subparagraph (A) or trusts of the kind referred to in subparagraph (B), and other persons. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 11)

subsection.content: Where a person obtains a pecuniary advantage in connection with the commission of an offence, or the commission of one or more organized crimes, he is to be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as if he had obtained in connection with that offence or those crimes, as the case may be, a sum of money equal to the value of that advantage, and the other provisions of this Ordinance shall be construed accordingly. (Added 87 of 1997 s. 36)

section.name: s13
section.heading: Application of procedure for enforcing confiscation orders

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this section, where the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, makes a confiscation order— (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 12; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the court shall also make an order—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: subject to subsection (1A), fixing the period within which the amount he is liable to pay under the confiscation order shall be duly paid; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: fixing a term of imprisonment which the defendant is to serve if any of that amount is not duly paid within that period (including paid by way of being recovered); and (Replaced 26 of 2002 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: section 114(1), (3), (4), (5), (6) and (7) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) shall apply as if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that amount were a fine imposed upon him by the court; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the term of imprisonment fixed under this section were a term fixed under section 114(1)(c) of that Ordinance.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The court shall not under subsection (1)(a)(i) fix a period longer than 6 months unless it is satisfied that there are special circumstances which justify it doing so. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)
The terms set out in column 2 of the following table shall be the maximum terms of imprisonment under subsection (1) applicable respectively to the amounts set out opposite thereto.

tr.td: An amount exceeding $200,000 but not exceeding $500,000
An amount exceeding $500,000 but not exceeding $1 million
An amount exceeding $1 million but not exceeding $2.5 million
An amount exceeding $2.5 million but not exceeding $10 million

subsection.content: Subsections (1) and (2) shall apply in relation to the District Court. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 12)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that no limitation on the jurisdiction of the District Court as to the imposition of penalties set out in section 82 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) shall be construed so as to prejudice the operation of subsection (3). (Added 90 of 1995 s. 12)

subsection.leadIn: Where the defendant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: becomes liable to serve a term of imprisonment fixed under this section in respect of a confiscation order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is also liable to serve a term of imprisonment or detention in respect of the offence or offences concerned,

subsection.continued: the term of imprisonment mentioned in paragraph (a) shall not begin to run until after the end of the term of imprisonment or detention mentioned in paragraph (b).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (4)—

paragraph.name: a
