paragraph.content: consecutive terms and terms which are wholly or partly concurrent shall be treated as a single term; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: there shall be disregarded—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any sentence suspended under section 109B of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) which has not taken effect at the time the defendant becomes liable to a term of imprisonment under this section; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any term of imprisonment fixed under section 114(1) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) for which the defendant has not at that time been committed.

subsection.content: Sections 86 and 109A of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) shall not apply in relation to fixing a term of imprisonment under this section. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 12)
This section shall not apply in relation to a confiscation order where section 8(1)(a)(ii) or (7A) is applicable. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 12)

At the end of each day’s sitting of the Court of First Instance or the District Court, the Registrar of the High Court or District Court, as the case may be, shall deliver (or cause to be delivered) to the Commissioner of Correctional Services a certificate, in the form specified in Schedule 5, in respect of each term of imprisonment fixed under this section. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 12. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

A certificate referred to in subsection (8) shall be a sufficient warrant to the Commissioner of Correctional Services for receiving into his custody the defendant named in the certificate and for carrying into effect the term of imprisonment fixed under this section in respect of that defendant. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 12)

section.name: s14
section.heading: Cases in which restraint orders and charging orders may be made

subsection.leadIn: The powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 15(1) and 16(1) are exercisable where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: proceedings have been instituted in Hong Kong against the defendant for a specified offence or—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an application for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the defendant where section 8(1)(a)(ii) or (7A) is applicable; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an application has been made under section 20(1A) in respect of a confiscation order made against the defendant; (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 13)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proceedings have not, or the application has not, as the case may be, been concluded; (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 13. Amended 26 of 2002 s. 3)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (1A), if section 2(15)(aa) is applicable to an offence, the Court of First Instance is satisfied that, in all the circumstances of the case, there is reasonable cause to believe that the defendant may be charged with the offence after further investigation is carried out; and (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the Court of First Instance is satisfied that there is reasonable cause to believe—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of an application referred to in paragraph (a)(ii), that the Court of First Instance will be satisfied as specified in section 20(1A);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in any other case, that the defendant has benefited from that specified offence. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 13)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (1B), where a power conferred on the Court of First Instance by section 15(1) or 16(1) is exercisable only on the ground mentioned in subsection (1)(ba), then the Court of First Instance shall specify a date on which any restraint order or charging order arising from that ground shall expire, being a date—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), not later than is reasonably necessary for the purposes of the investigation concerned mentioned in subsection (1)(ba); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any case, not later than 6 months after the date on which that order is made. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may extend a restraint order or charging order mentioned in subsection (1A)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the ground only that the Court of First Instance is satisfied that the defendant will be charged with the offence concerned after further investigation is carried out;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (c), not longer than is reasonably necessary for the purposes of that investigation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any case, for not more than 6 months. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Those powers are also exercisable where the Court of First Instance is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that, whether by the laying of an information or otherwise, a person is to be charged with a specified offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there is reasonable cause to believe that he has benefited from that specified offence.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of sections 15 and 16, in relation to the exercise of those powers at any time before proceedings have been instituted, references in this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the defendant shall be construed as references to the person referred to in subsection (2)(a);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the prosecutor shall be construed as references to the person who the Court of First Instance is satisfied is to have the conduct of the case for the prosecution in the proposed proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to realisable property shall be construed as if, immediately before that time, proceedings had been instituted against the person referred to in subsection (2)(a) for a specified offence.

subsection.content: Where the Court of First Instance has made an order under section 15(1) or 16(1) by virtue of subsection (2), the Court of First Instance shall discharge the order if proceedings in respect of the offence are not instituted within such time as the Court of First Instance considers reasonable.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Restraint orders

subsection.def: The Court of First Instance may by order (referred to in this Ordinance as a restraint order (限制令)) prohibit any person from dealing with any realisable property, subject to such conditions and exceptions as may be specified in the order. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: A restraint order may apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to all realisable property held by a specified person, whether the property is described in the order or not; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to realisable property held by a specified person, being property transferred to him after the making of the order.

subsection.content: This section shall not have effect in relation to any property for the time being subject to a charge under section 16.

subsection.leadIn: A restraint order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be made only on an application by the prosecutor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be made on an ex parte application to a judge in chambers; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: shall provide for notice to be given to persons affected by the order.

subsection.leadIn: A restraint order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be discharged or varied in relation to any property; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall be discharged on the conclusion of the proceedings or application concerned. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 14)

subsection.content: An application for the discharge or variation of a restraint order may be made by any person affected by it.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court of First Instance has made a restraint order, the Court of First Instance may at any time appoint a receiver—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to take possession of any realisable property; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in accordance with the directions of the Court of First Instance, to manage or otherwise deal with any property in respect of which he is appointed,

subsection.continued: subject to such exceptions and conditions as may be specified by the Court of First Instance; and may require any person having possession of property in respect of which a receiver is appointed under this section to give possession of it to the receiver. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: Where the Court of First Instance has made a restraint order, an authorized officer may, for the purpose of preventing any realisable property being removed from Hong Kong, seize the property. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
Property seized under subsection (9) shall be dealt with in accordance with the directions of the Court of First Instance. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Where any property specified in a restraint order is immovable property the order shall, for the purposes of the Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be deemed to be an instrument affecting land; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be registrable as such in the Land Registry under that Ordinance in such manner as the Land Registrar thinks fit.

subsection.content: An authorized officer may, by notice in writing served on a person who holds any realisable property the subject of a restraint order, require the person to deliver to the authorized officer, to the extent that it is practicable to do so, documents, or copies of documents, or any other information (in whatever form), in his possession or control which may assist the authorized officer to determine the value of the property. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

A person who receives a notice under subsection (12) shall, as soon as is practicable after receipt of the notice, comply with the notice to the extent that it is practicable to do so taking into account the nature of the realisable property the subject of the restraint order concerned. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: A disclosure made in order to comply with a requirement under subsection (12)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not be treated as a breach of any restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by contract or by any enactment, rule of conduct or other provision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall not render the person who made it liable in damages for any loss arising out of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the disclosure;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any act done or omitted to be done in relation to the property concerned in consequence of the disclosure. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes subsection (13) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)
A person who knowingly deals in any realisable property in contravention of a restraint order commits an offence. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (16) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $500,000 or to the value of the realisable property the subject of the restraint order concerned which has been dealt with in contravention of that order, whichever is the greater, and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

section.name: s16
section.heading: Charging orders in respect of land, securities, etc.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may make a charging order on realisable property for securing the payment to the Government— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where a confiscation order has not been made, of an amount equal to the value from time to time of the property charged; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, of an amount not exceeding the amount payable under the confiscation order.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Ordinance, a charging order is an order made under this section imposing on any such realisable property as may be specified in the order a charge for securing the payment of money to the Government.

subsection.leadIn: A charging order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be made only on an application by the prosecutor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be made on an ex parte application to a judge in chambers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: shall provide for notice to be given to persons affected by the order; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: may be made subject to such conditions as the Court of First Instance thinks fit and, without prejudice to the generality of this paragraph, such conditions as it thinks fit as to the time when the charge is to become effective. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), a charge may be imposed by a charging order only on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any interest in realisable property, being an interest held beneficially by the defendant or by a person to whom the defendant has directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in any asset of a kind specified in Schedule 3; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under any trust; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any interest in realisable property held by a person as trustee of a trust if the interest is in such an asset or is an interest under another trust and a charge may by virtue of paragraph (a) be imposed by a charging order on the whole beneficial interest under the first mentioned trust.

subsection.content: In any case where a charge is imposed by a charging order on any interest in an asset of a kind specified in Schedule 3, the Court of First Instance may provide for the charge to extend to any interest, dividend or other distribution payable and any bonus issue in respect of the asset. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: In relation to a charging order, the Court of First Instance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make an order discharging or varying it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall make an order discharging the charging order—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on the conclusion of the proceedings or application concerned; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on payment into the Court of First Instance of the amount payment of which is secured by the charge. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 15. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: An application for the discharge or variation of a charging order may be made by any person affected by it.

Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, a charge imposed by a charging order shall have the like effect and shall be enforceable in the same manner as an equitable charge created by the person holding the beneficial interest or, as the case may be, the trustee, by writing under his hand.

An authorized officer may, by notice in writing served on a person who holds any realisable property the subject of a charging order, require the person to deliver to the authorized officer, to the extent that it is practicable to do so, documents, or copies of documents, or any other information (in whatever form), in his possession or control which may assist the authorized officer to determine the value of the property. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

A person who receives a notice under subsection (9) shall, as soon as is practicable after receipt of the notice, comply with the notice to the extent that it is practicable to do so taking into account the nature of the realisable property the subject of the charging order concerned. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: A disclosure made in order to comply with a requirement under subsection (9)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not be treated as a breach of any restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by contract or by any enactment, rule of conduct or other provision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall not render the person who made it liable in damages for any loss arising out of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the disclosure;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any act done or omitted to be done in relation to the property concerned in consequence of the disclosure. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes subsection (10) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)
A person who knowingly deals in any realisable property in contravention of a charging order commits an offence. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (13) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $500,000 or to the value of the realisable property the subject of the charging order concerned which has been dealt with in contravention of that order, whichever is the greater, and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 3)

section.name: s17
section.heading: Realisation of property

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the order is not subject to appeal or review within the meaning of section 2(17); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the proceedings in which it was made have not been concluded,

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance may, on an application by the prosecutor, exercise the powers conferred by subsections (2) to (6).

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may appoint a receiver in respect of realisable property.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may empower a receiver appointed under subsection (2), under section 15 or in pursuance of a charging order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enforce any charge imposed under section 16 on realisable property or on any interest, dividend or other distribution payable and any bonus issue in respect of such property; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to any realisable property other than property for the time being subject to a charge under section 16, to take possession of the property subject to such conditions or exceptions as may be specified by the Court of First Instance.

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may order any person having possession of realisable property to give possession of it to any such receiver.
The Court of First Instance may empower any such receiver to realise any realisable property in such manner as the Court of First Instance may direct.

The Court of First Instance may order any person holding an interest in realisable property to make such payment to the receiver in respect of any beneficial interest held by the defendant or, as the case may be, the recipient of a gift caught by this Ordinance as the Court of First Instance may direct and the Court of First Instance may, on the payment being made, by order transfer, grant or extinguish any interest in the property.
Subsections (4) to (6) do not apply to property for the time being subject to a charge under section 16.

The Court of First Instance shall not in respect of any property exercise the powers conferred by subsection (3)(a), (5) or (6) unless a reasonable opportunity has been given for persons holding any interest in the property to make representations to the Court of First Instance.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Application of proceeds of realisation and other sums

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), the following sums in the hands of a receiver appointed under section 15 or 17 or in pursuance of a charging order, that is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proceeds of the enforcement of any charge imposed under section 16;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: any other sums, being property held by the defendant,

subsection.continued: shall first be applied in payment of such expenses incurred by a person acting as an insolvency officer as are payable under section 23(2) and then shall, after such payments (if any) as the Court of First Instance may direct have been made out of those sums— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: be payable to the Registrar; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: be applied on the defendant’s behalf towards the satisfaction of the confiscation order in the manner provided by subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: If, after the amount payable under the confiscation order has been fully paid, any such sums remain in the hands of such a receiver, the receiver shall distribute those sums—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: among such of those who held property which has been realised under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in such proportions,

subsection.continued: as the Court of First Instance may direct after giving a reasonable opportunity for such persons to make representations to the Court of First Instance. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: The receipt of any sum by the Registrar on account of an amount payable under a confiscation order shall reduce the amount so payable, but the Registrar shall apply the sum received for the purposes specified in this section and in the order so specified.
The Registrar shall first pay any expenses incurred by a person acting as an insolvency officer and payable under section 23(2) but not already paid under subsection (1).
If the sum was paid to the Registrar by a receiver appointed under section 15 or 17 or in pursuance of a charging order, the Registrar shall next pay the receiver’s remuneration and expenses.

subsection.leadIn: After making—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any payment required by subsection (4); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in a case to which subsection (5) applies, any payment required by that subsection,

subsection.continued: the Registrar shall reimburse any amount paid under section 24(2).

subsection.content: Any balance in the hands of the Registrar after he has made all payments required by the foregoing subsections shall be paid into the general revenue. (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 17)

section.name: s19
section.heading: Exercise of powers by Court of First Instance or receiver

subsection.content: This section applies to the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 15 to 18, or on a receiver appointed under section 15 or 17 or in pursuance of a charging order. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

Subject to subsections (3), (4), (5) and (6), the powers shall be exercised with a view to making available for satisfying the confiscation order or, as the case may be, any confiscation order that may be made in the defendant’s case the value for the time being of realisable property held by any person by the realisation of such property.

In the case of realisable property held by a person to whom the defendant has directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance, the powers shall be exercised with a view to realising no more than the value for the time being of the gift.
The powers shall be exercised with a view to allowing any person other than the defendant or the recipient of any such gift to retain or recover the value of any property held by him.
An order may be made or other action taken in respect of a debt owed by the Government.
In exercising those powers, no account shall be taken of any obligations of the defendant or of the recipient of any such gift which conflict with the obligation to satisfy the confiscation order.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Variation of confiscation orders

subsection.leadIn: If, on an application by the prosecutor or the defendant (or, in the case of a defendant who has died, his personal representative on his behalf) in respect of a confiscation order, the Court of First Instance is satisfied that the realisable property is inadequate for the payment of any amount remaining to be recovered under the confiscation order, the Court of First Instance shall make an order— (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 19)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: substituting for the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order such lesser amount as the Court of First Instance thinks just in all the circumstances of the case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: substituting for the term of imprisonment fixed under section 13 in respect of the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order a shorter term determined in accordance with that section in respect of the lesser amount.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: If, on an application by the prosecutor made in respect of a confiscation order, the Court of First Instance is satisfied that any of the conditions referred to in subsection (1B) are fulfilled, the Court of First Instance may make an order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: substituting for the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order such greater amount as the Court of First Instance thinks just in all the circumstances of the case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: substituting for the term of imprisonment fixed under section 13 in respect of the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order a greater term determined in accordance with that section in respect of the greater amount. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 19)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (1A) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the value of the defendant’s proceeds of any specified offence or offences or organized crime was greater than the value of the defendant’s proceeds of the specified offence or offences or organized crime, as the case may be, assessed by the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, at the time of the making of the confiscation order;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the amount realised from the defendant’s proceeds of the specified offence or offences or organized crime, as the case may be, is greater than the amount the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, assessed to be the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 19)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section— (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 19)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of realisable property held by a person who has been adjudged bankrupt or whose estate has been sequestrated the Court of First Instance shall take into account the extent to which any property held by him may be distributed among creditors; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court of First Instance may disregard any inadequacy in the realisable property which appears to the Court of First Instance to be attributable wholly or partly to anything done by the defendant for the purpose of preserving any property held by a person to whom the defendant had directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance from any risk of realisation under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: No application shall be entertained by the Court of First Instance under subsection (1A) if it is made after the end of the period of 6 years beginning with the date on which the confiscation order concerned was made. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 19)

section.name: s21
section.heading: Bankruptcy of defendant, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person who holds realisable property is adjudged bankrupt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: property for the time being subject to a restraint order made before the order adjudging him bankrupt; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any proceeds of property realised by virtue of section 15(7) or 17(5) or (6) for the time being in the hands of a receiver appointed under section 15 or 17,

subsection.continued: are excluded from the property of the bankrupt for the purposes of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6).

subsection.leadIn: Where a person has been adjudged bankrupt, the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 15 to 18 shall not be exercised in relation to— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: property for the time being comprised in the property of the bankrupt for the purposes of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: property which is to be applied for the benefit of creditors of the bankrupt by virtue of a condition imposed under section 30A(9) of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6). (Amended 76 of 1996 s. 97)

subsection.content: Nothing in the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) shall be taken as restricting, or enabling the restriction of, the exercise of the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 15 to 18. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not affect the enforcement of a charging order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: made before the order adjudging the person bankrupt; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on property which was subject to a restraint order when the order adjudging him bankrupt was made.

subsection.content: Where, in the case of a debtor, an interim trustee stands appointed under section 13 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) and any property of the debtor is subject to a restraint order, the powers conferred on the interim trustee by virtue of that Ordinance do not apply to property for the time being subject to the restraint order. (Amended 18 of 2005 s. 48)

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is adjudged bankrupt and has directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a court shall not make an order under—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: section 49 or 50 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or (Amended 76 of 1996 s. 97)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: section 60 of the Conveyancing and Property Ordinance (Cap. 219),

paragraph.continued: in respect of the making of a gift at any time when—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: proceedings for a specified offence have been instituted against him but have not been concluded;

subparagraph.name: B
I
subparagraph.content: for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the person where section 8(1)(a)(ii) or (7A) is applicable; or

subparagraph.name: II
subparagraph.content: has been made under section 20(1A) in respect of a confiscation order made against the person,

subparagraph.continued: and the application has not been concluded; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: property of the person to whom the gift was made is subject to a restraint order or charging order; and (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 20)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any order made under any of the sections referred to in paragraph (a)(i) or (ii) after the conclusion of the proceedings or application shall take into account any realisation under this Ordinance of property held by the person to whom the gift was made. (Replaced 90 of 1995 s. 20)

section.name: s22
section.heading: Winding up of company holding realisable property

subsection.leadIn: Where realisable property is held by a company and an order for the winding up of the company has been made or a resolution has been passed by the company for voluntary winding up, the functions of the liquidator (or any provisional liquidator) shall not be exercisable in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: property for the time being subject to a restraint order made before the relevant time; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any proceeds of property realised by virtue of section 15(7) or 17(5) or (6) for the time being in the hands of a receiver appointed under section 15 or 17.

subsection.leadIn: Where, in the case of a company, such an order has been made or such a resolution has been passed, the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 15 to 18 shall not be exercised in relation to any realisable property held by the company in relation to which the functions of the liquidator are exercisable— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: so as to inhibit him from exercising those functions for the purpose of distributing any property held by the company to the company’s creditors; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so as to prevent the payment out of any property of expenses (including the remuneration of the liquidator or any provisional liquidator) properly incurred in the winding up in respect of the property.

subsection.content: Nothing in the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) or the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) shall be taken as restricting, or enabling the restriction of, the exercise of the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 15 to 18. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Subsection (3) shall apply to any proceedings relating to an appeal, further appeal or review against any exercise of the powers referred to in that subsection as if the court hearing the appeal, further appeal or review, as the case may be, were the Court of First Instance. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 21. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
Subsection (2) does not affect the enforcement of a charging order made before the relevant time or on property which was subject to a restraint order at the relevant time.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: company (公司) means any company which may be wound up under the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

def.name: TheRelevantTime
def.leadIn: the relevant time (有關時間) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where no order for the winding up of the company has been made, the time of the passing of the resolution for voluntary winding up;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where such an order has been made and, before the presentation of the petition for the winding up of the company by the Court of First Instance, such a resolution had been passed by the company, the time of the passing of the resolution; and (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any other case where such an order has been made, the time of the making of the order.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Insolvency officers dealing with property subject to restraint order

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of any provision contained in the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6), the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) or any other Ordinance, where— (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any insolvency officer seizes or disposes of any property in relation to which his functions are not exercisable because it is for the time being subject to a restraint order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the time of the seizure or disposal he believes, and has reasonable grounds for believing, that he is entitled (whether in pursuance of an order of a court or otherwise) to seize or dispose of that property,

subsection.continued: he shall not be liable to any other person in respect of any loss or damage resulting from the seizure or disposal except in so far as the loss or damage is caused by his negligence; and the insolvency officer shall have a lien on the property, or the proceeds of its sale, for such of his expenses as were incurred in connection with the liquidation, bankruptcy or other proceedings in relation to which the seizure or disposal purported to take place and for so much of his remuneration as may reasonably be assigned for his acting in connection with those proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: Any insolvency officer who incurs expenses—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of such property as is mentioned in subsection (1)(a) and in so doing does not know and has no reasonable grounds to believe that the property is for the time being subject to a restraint order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other than in respect of such property as is so mentioned, being expenses which, but for the effect of a restraint order, might have been met by taking possession of and realising the property,

subsection.continued: shall be entitled (whether or not he has seized or disposed of that property so as to have a lien under that subsection) to payment of those expenses under section 18(1) or (4).

section.name: s24
section.heading: Receivers: supplementary provisions

subsection.leadIn: Where a receiver appointed under section 15 or 17 or in pursuance of a charging order takes any action—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to property which is not realisable property, being action which he would be entitled to take if it were such property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: believing, and having reasonable grounds for believing, that he is entitled to take that action in relation to that property,

subsection.continued: he shall not be liable to any person in respect of any loss or damage resulting from his action except in so far as the loss or damage is caused by his negligence.

subsection.content: Any amount due in respect of the remuneration and expenses of a receiver so appointed shall, if no sum is available to be applied in payment of it under section 18(5), be paid by the prosecutor or, in a case where proceedings for a specified offence are not instituted, by the person on whose application the receiver was appointed.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Dealing with property known or believed to represent proceeds of indictable offence

subsection.content: Subject to section 25A, a person commits an offence if, knowing or having reasonable grounds to believe that any property in whole or in part directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of an indictable offence, he deals with that property.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings against a person for an offence under subsection (1), it is a defence to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he intended to disclose to an authorized officer such knowledge, suspicion or matter as is mentioned in section 25A(1) in relation to the act in contravention of subsection (1) concerned; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is reasonable excuse for his failure to make disclosure in accordance with section 25A(2).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $5,000,000 and to imprisonment for 14 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.content: In this section and section 25A, references to an indictable offence include a reference to conduct which would constitute an indictable offence if it had occurred in Hong Kong.

section.name: s25A
section.heading: Disclosure of knowledge or suspicion that property represents proceeds, etc. of indictable offence

subsection.leadIn: Where a person knows or suspects that any property—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in whole or in part directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was used in connection with; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is intended to be used in connection with,

subsection.continued: an indictable offence, he shall as soon as it is reasonable for him to do so disclose that knowledge or suspicion, together with any matter on which that knowledge or suspicion is based, to an authorized officer.

subsection.leadIn: If a person who has made a disclosure referred to in subsection (1) does any act in contravention of section 25(1) (whether before or after such disclosure), and the disclosure relates to that act, he does not commit an offence under that section if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that disclosure is made before he does that act and he does that act with the consent of an authorized officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that disclosure is made—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: after he does that act;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on his initiative; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: as soon as it is reasonable for him to make it.

subsection.leadIn: A disclosure referred to in subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not be treated as a breach of any restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by contract or by any enactment, rule of conduct or other provision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall not render the person who made it liable in damages for any loss arising out of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the disclosure;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any act done or omitted to be done in relation to the property concerned in consequence of the disclosure.

subsection.content: In the case of a person who was in employment at the relevant time, this section shall have effect in relation to disclosures to the appropriate person in accordance with the procedure established by his employer for the making of such disclosures as it has effect in relation to disclosures to an authorized officer.

A person commits an offence if, knowing or suspecting that a disclosure has been made under subsection (1) or (4), he discloses to any other person any matter which is likely to prejudice any investigation which might be conducted following that first-mentioned disclosure.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings against a person for an offence under subsection (5), it is a defence to prove—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that he did not know or suspect that the disclosure concerned was likely to be prejudicial in the way referred to in that subsection; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that he had lawful authority or reasonable excuse for making that disclosure.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (5) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

subsection.leadIn: Information obtained under or by virtue of a disclosure referred to in subsection (1) may be disclosed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by any authorized officer to the Department of Justice, the Hong Kong Police Force, the Customs and Excise Department, the Immigration Department, and the Independent Commission Against Corruption, for the purpose of combating crime; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by any authorized officer to the authorities or persons responsible for investigating or preventing crime, or handling the disclosure of knowledge or suspicion on property relating to crime, of any place outside Hong Kong which the authorized officer thinks fit, for the purpose of combating crime. (Added 21 of 2004 s. 24)

subsection.content: Subsection (9) is without prejudice to any other right to disclose information obtained under or by virtue of a disclosure referred to in subsection (1) that may exist apart from subsection (9). (Added 21 of 2004 s. 24)

section.name: s26
section.heading: Restriction on revealing disclosure under section 25A

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), no witness in any civil or criminal proceedings shall be obliged—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to reveal that a disclosure was made under section 25A(1) or (4); (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 23)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to reveal the identity of any person as the person making the disclosure; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to answer any question if the answer would lead, or would tend to lead, to the revealing of any fact or matter referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) shall not apply in any proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for an offence under section 25 or 25A or this section; or (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 23)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the court is of the opinion that justice cannot fully be done between the parties without revealing the disclosure or the identity of any person as the person making the disclosure.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (4), (5) and (6), no person shall publish or broadcast any information so as to reveal or suggest—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a disclosure was made under section 25A(1) or (4); or (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 23)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the identity of any person as the person making the disclosure.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: includes a report of any civil or criminal proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not include information published for statistical purposes by, or under the authority of, the Government.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) shall not apply in respect of proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: against the person making the disclosure for an offence under section 25 or 25A; or (Amended 90 of 1995 s. 23)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for an offence under this section.

subsection.content: The court or a magistrate may, if satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so, by order dispense with the requirements of subsection (3) to such extent as may be specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: If information is published or broadcast in contravention of subsection (3), each of the following persons—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of publication as part of a newspaper or periodical publication, any proprietor, editor, publisher and distributor thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a publication otherwise than as part of a newspaper or periodical publication, any person who publishes it and any person who distributes it;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a broadcast, any person who broadcasts the information and, if the information is contained in a programme, any person who transmits or provides the programme and any person having functions in relation to the programme corresponding to those of the editor of a newspaper or periodical publication,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: Proceedings for an offence under this section shall not be instituted except with the consent of the Secretary for Justice. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: publish (出版) means publish in writing.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Sentencing in respect of specified offences

subsection.content: This section applies where, in proceedings in the District Court or the Court of First Instance, a person has been convicted of a specified offence. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: The prosecution may furnish information to the court regarding any or all of the following—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: the prevalence of that specified offence;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the nature and extent of any harm, whether direct or indirect, caused to the community by recent occurrences of that specified offence;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the nature and extent of the total benefit, whether financial or otherwise, accruing directly or indirectly to any person from recent occurrences of that specified offence.

subsection.content: Only information that would be admissible in evidence in criminal proceedings (including proceedings in respect of sentencing) may be furnished to the court under subsection (2).

If the prosecution so requests, the court shall determine whether the evidence adduced at the trial or, if the conviction followed a plea of guilty, the matters accepted by the court prior to conviction show that the specified offence was an organized crime.

The prosecution shall not request a determination under subsection (4) unless it has given notice to the person of its intention to seek such a determination, and unless such notice has been given prior to the plea last entered by the person or within such further time as may have been allowed by the court under subsection (6).

If a person has pleaded guilty to a specified offence and it appears to the court, having regard to the time at which the prosecution was informed of the accused’s intention to plead guilty, that it would be in the interests of justice to allow the prosecution further time within which to give the notice provided for in subsection (5), the court may order accordingly and may specify such period for that purpose as it considers reasonable in the circumstances, and if notice is given pursuant to an order under this subsection the court may allow the accused to withdraw his plea of guilty.

The court shall not make a determination under subsection (4) that a specified offence was an organized crime unless, subsequent to his receipt of the notice required to be given under subsection (5), the person convicted has been given an opportunity to be heard on the matter.

If in making a determination under subsection (4) the court determines that the specified offence was an organized crime by reason of its connection with the activities of a particular triad society, the prosecution may furnish information to the court regarding the nature and extent of those activities and the way in which the offence was connected with those activities.
The court may receive and take into account regarding a matter referred to in subsection (8) any information which it considers reliable in the circumstances.

Where the prosecution seeks to furnish information to a court under this section regarding any matter referred to in subsection (2) or (8), the court shall allow the person convicted an opportunity to object to the reception of the information, and where any such information is received by the court the court shall allow the person an opportunity to furnish information regarding that same matter.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (12) and (13), where a court is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the specified offence was an organized crime; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as to any information furnished under subsection (2) or (8),

subsection.continued: or where any such matter is agreed by the person convicted, the court shall have regard to such matter when it passes a sentence on the person for the relevant specified offence and may, if it thinks fit, pass a sentence on the person for that offence that is more severe than the sentence it would, in the absence of such matter, have passed.

subsection.content: If an application has been made for a confiscation order under section 8, the court shall not have regard for the purpose of subsection (11) to any proceeds of a specified offence or organized crime to which the application for the confiscation order relates.
A sentence passed pursuant to subsection (11) shall not exceed the maximum penalty permitted by law for the offence.

This section operates without prejudice to any other information that may be furnished to a court before a person is sentenced, or to any other information to which a court shall or may have regard when sentencing a person for any offence.
This section does not apply to a person who is convicted of a specified offence committed before the commencement of this section.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Disclosure of information held by public bodies

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4), the Court of First Instance may, on an application by the prosecutor, order any material mentioned in subsection (3) which is in the possession of a public body to be produced to the Court of First Instance within such period as the Court of First Instance may specify.

subsection.leadIn: The power to make an order under subsection (1) is exercisable if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 15(1) and 16(1) are exercisable by virtue of section 14(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those powers are exercisable by virtue of section 14(2) and the Court of First Instance has made a restraint or charging order which has not been discharged,

subsection.continued: but where the power to make an order under subsection (1) is exercisable by virtue only of paragraph (b), section 14(3) shall apply for the purposes of this section as it applies for the purposes of sections 15 and 16.

subsection.leadIn: The material referred to in subsection (1) is any material which—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: has been made by an officer of a public body in relation to the defendant or such a person; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is correspondence which passed between an officer of a public body and the defendant or such a person,

subsection.continued: and an order under that subsection may require the production of all such material or of a particular description of such material, being material in the possession of the body concerned.

subsection.content: An order under subsection (1) shall not require the production of any material unless it appears to the Court of First Instance that the material is likely to contain information that would facilitate the exercise of the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 15 to 17 or on a receiver appointed under section 15 or 17 or in pursuance of a charging order.

The Court of First Instance may by order authorize the disclosure to such a receiver of any material produced under subsection (1) or any part of such material; but the Court of First Instance shall not make an order under this subsection unless a reasonable opportunity has been given for an officer of the public body to make representations to the Court of First Instance.

Material disclosed in pursuance of an order under subsection (5) may, subject to any conditions contained in the order, be further disclosed for the purposes of the functions under this Ordinance of the receiver or the Court of First Instance.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may by order authorize the disclosure to an authorized officer of any material produced under subsection (1) or any part of such material; but the Court of First Instance shall not make an order under this subsection unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reasonable opportunity has been given for an officer of the public body to make representations to the Court of First Instance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it appears to the Court of First Instance that the material is likely to be relevant in exercising functions relating to the investigation of specified offences.

subsection.content: Material disclosed in pursuance of an order under subsection (7) may, subject to any conditions contained in the order, be further disclosed for the purposes of functions relating to the investigation of specified offences.

Material may be produced or disclosed in pursuance of this section notwithstanding any obligation as to secrecy or other restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by statute or otherwise.

An order under subsection (1) and, in the case of material in the possession of a public body, an order under section 4(2) may require any officer of the public body (whether named in the order or not) who may for the time being be in possession of the material concerned to comply with it, and such an order shall be served as if the proceedings were civil proceedings against the Government. (Amended 13 of 1999 s. 3)

def.name: PublicBody
def.leadIn: In this section, public body (公共機構) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any Government department; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any body specified by the Chief Executive under subsection (12). (Amended 13 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may, by notice in the Gazette, specify a body to be a public body for the purposes of this section. (Amended 13 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s29
section.heading: Compensation

subsection.leadIn: If an investigation is begun against a person for a specified offence or offences and any of the following circumstances occur, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no proceedings are instituted against that person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceedings are instituted against that person but do not result in his conviction for any specified offence (including any proceedings referred to in section 8(1)(a)(ii) where no confiscation order is made against that person);

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.leadIn: that person absconds after proceedings are instituted against him and subsequently—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: he ceases to be an absconder; and

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: those proceedings are continued or reinstituted but do not result in his conviction for any specified offence; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: those proceedings are not continued or reinstituted within a reasonable period after it is known to the Secretary for Justice that he has ceased to be an absconder; or (Added 90 of 1995 s. 25. Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: proceedings are instituted against that person and he is convicted of one or more specified offences, but

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the conviction or convictions concerned are quashed; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he is granted a pardon in respect of the conviction or convictions concerned,

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance may, on application by a person who held property which was realisable property (or, in the case of such a person who has died, his personal representative on his behalf), order compensation to be paid by the Government to the applicant if, having regard to all the circumstances, it considers it appropriate to make such an order.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance shall not order compensation to be paid under subsection (1) unless it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (3A), that there has been some serious default on the part of any person concerned in the investigation or prosecution of the offence or offences concerned; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the applicant has suffered loss in consequence of anything done in relation to the property by or in pursuance of an order of the Court of First Instance under sections 15 to 17.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3A), the Court of First Instance shall not order compensation to be paid under subsection (1) in any case where it appears to the Court of First Instance that the investigation would have been continued, or the proceedings would have been instituted or continued, as the case may be, if the serious default had not occurred.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Subsections (2)(a) and (3) shall not apply to any case to which subsection (1)(ba) is applicable. (Added 90 of 1995 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to subsection (1), where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a disclosure is made by any person in accordance with section 25A(2) in relation to any property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in consequence of the disclosure and for the purposes of an investigation or prosecution in respect of a specified offence or offences any act is done or omitted to be done in relation to that property; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no proceedings are instituted against any person in respect of that offence or those offences or no order is made by the Court of First Instance under section 15 or 16 in relation to that property,

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance may, on application by a person who held the property, order compensation to be paid by the Government to the applicant if, having regard to all the circumstances, it considers it appropriate to make such an order.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance shall not order compensation to be paid under subsection (4) unless it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there has been some serious default on the part of any person concerned in the investigation or prosecution of the offence or offences concerned and that, but for that default, the act or omission referred to in subsection (4)(b) would not have occurred; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant has, in consequence of the act or omission referred to in subsection (4)(b), suffered loss in relation to the property.

subsection.content: The amount of compensation to be paid under this section shall be such as the Court of First Instance thinks just in all the circumstances of the case.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Rules of court
section.text: The power to make rules of court under section 54 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4) shall include power to make rules of court for the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Amendment of amount in section 8(4) and Schedules
section.content: Subject to the approval of the Legislative Council, the Chief Executive in Council may by order amend the amount specified in section 8(4) and the Schedules.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Savings
section.content: This Ordinance operates without prejudice to the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance (Cap. 405).
